heading.title: <h1>-<h6> - Heading Elements
heading.heading: Heading Elements
content: HTML provides six levels of heading elements: <h1> through <h6>. <h1> is the most important and largest, while <h6> is the least important and smallest.
Headings help organize content, improve accessibility, and provide structure for both users and search engines.
Search engines use the headings to index the structure and content of your web pages.
Users often skim a page by its headings. It is important to use headings to show the document structure.
Use <h1> for the main title of the page (only once per page), and use <h2> to <h6> for sub-sections and further subdivisions.

Each heading level has a different default size and boldness, making the document hierarchy visually clear. By default, <h1> is the largest and <h6> is the smallest. You can change the size of any heading using CSS.
Example: A blog post might use <h1> for the post title, <h2> for section headings, and <h3> for sub-sections within those sections.

examples.label: All Heading Levels
examples.code:
This is an h1 heading

This is an h2 heading

This is an h3 heading

This is an h4 heading

This is an h5 heading
This is an h6 heading

heading.note: Note: Use HTML headings for headings only. Don't use headings to make text BIG or bold.

editor.initialHtml:
This is an h1 heading

This is an h2 heading

This is an h3 heading

This is an h4 heading

This is an h5 heading
This is an h6 heading

paragraph.title: - Paragraph Element
paragraph.heading: Paragraph Element
paragraph.note:
Note: Paragraphs are for blocks of text. Don't use

for headings or lists.
content:
The

element defines a paragraph of text. It is a block-level element and automatically adds space before and after itself.
Paragraphs are used to group related sentences and make your content easier to read.

You can use multiple

elements to separate different ideas or topics.

examples.label:
Basic

Example
examples.code: This is a paragraph of text in HTML.

editor.initialHtml:
This is a paragraph in HTML.

Paragraphs help structure your content.

anchor.title: <a> - Anchor Element
anchor.heading: Anchor Element
content: The <a> element creates hyperlinks, which allow users to navigate to other web pages, files, email addresses, or specific sections of a page.
It requires the 'href' attribute to specify the destination URL.
You can also use target attributes like '_blank' to open links in a new tab.
Anchors can link to external sites, internal pages, or even specific points within the same page using IDs.
Example: Visit Example

examples.label: Open in New Tab
examples.code: Visit Example in New Tab

anchor.note: Note: Always use descriptive link text for accessibility and SEO.

bold.title: <b> - Bold Text
bold.heading: Bold Text
content: The <b> element makes text bold without adding extra importance or emphasis.
It is a purely visual change and should not be confused with <strong>, which conveys importance.
Use <b> for styling purposes only, such as highlighting keywords visually.
bold.note: Note: Use <strong> instead if the text has semantic importance.

strong.title: <strong> - Strong Importance
strong.heading: Strong Element
content: The <strong> element indicates that the text has strong importance, seriousness, or urgency.
Browsers typically render <strong> text in bold, but the semantic meaning is more important.
Screen readers will emphasize <strong> text, making it important for accessibility.
strong.note: Note: Use <strong> when meaning matters, and <b> for purely visual boldness.

br.title: - Line Break
br.heading: Line Break
content:
The
element inserts a single line break within text.
It is an empty element, meaning it has no closing tag.

Use
for small breaks, such as in addresses or poems, but avoid overusing it for layout purposes.

examples.label: Line Break Example
examples.code:
This is the first line.
This is the second line.

br.note:
Note: Use CSS for spacing instead of multiple
tags.

editor.initialHtml:
This is the first line.
This is the second line.

hr.title: <hr> - Horizontal Rule
hr.heading: Horizontal Rule
content: The <hr> element represents a thematic break between paragraph-level elements.
It is often displayed as a horizontal line and can be styled with CSS.
It is an empty element and does not require a closing tag.
hr.note: Note: Use <hr> for meaning, not just decoration. Style with CSS if needed.
